title: Topic Modeling on Text Corpus
prompt: Act as an NLP Data Scientist. Apply topic modeling techniques (e.g., Latent Dirichlet Allocation - LDA) to a corpus of text documents {{Document Set Description}} to discover underlying themes. Include: 1) Text preprocessing (cleaning, vectorization like TF-IDF), 2) Training the topic model (specifying number of topics), 3) Interpreting the topics based on top words, 4) Visualizing topic distributions.

title: Analyzing Clinical Trial Data (Conceptual)
prompt: Act as a Biostatistician. Outline the key statistical analysis steps involved in analyzing data from a randomized controlled clinical trial comparing {{Treatment Group}} vs. {{Control Group}} for the primary endpoint {{Primary Endpoint Metric}}. Include: 1) Baseline characteristic comparison, 2) Analysis of the primary endpoint (e.g., t-test, ANOVA, logistic regression), 3) Handling missing data, 4) Subgroup analyses (if planned), 5) Safety data analysis.

title: Creating Effective Tooltips for Charts
prompt: Act as a Data Visualization Designer. Provide best practices for designing effective tooltips (hover text) for interactive charts. Include tips on: 1) Content clarity and conciseness, 2) Formatting for readability, 3) Including relevant context or comparisons, 4) Avoiding information overload, 5) Ensuring responsiveness and performance.

title: Analyzing A/B Test with Bayesian Approach
prompt: Act as a Data Scientist. Explain how to analyze the results of an A/B test using a Bayesian approach, focusing on the posterior distribution of the difference between the variant and control groups for {{Key Metric}}. Include: 1) Defining prior distributions, 2) Calculating the posterior distribution, 3) Interpreting the probability that the variant is better than the control, 4) Discussing advantages over frequentist p-values (e.g., intuitive interpretation, ability to stop early).

title: Data Catalog Implementation Plan
prompt: Act as a Data Governance Lead. Outline a plan for implementing a data catalog within {{Organization/Department}}. Include: 1) Defining objectives and scope, 2) Selecting a data catalog tool/platform, 3) Defining metadata standards and collection processes, 4) Identifying data stewards and owners, 5) Rollout and training strategy, 6) Ongoing maintenance plan.

title: Detecting Seasonality in Time Series Data
prompt: Act as a Time Series Analyst. Describe methods for detecting seasonality in time series data {{Data Description}}. Include techniques like: 1) Visual inspection (e.g., time series plots, seasonal subseries plots), 2) Autocorrelation Function (ACF) plots, 3) Decomposition methods (e.g., moving averages, STL), 4) Statistical tests (e.g., Canova-Hansen test).

title: Analyzing User Feedback from App Store
prompt: Act as a Product Analyst. Analyze user feedback (reviews and ratings) from the {{App Store Name}} for the {{App Name}}. Include: 1) Trend analysis of ratings over time, 2) Sentiment analysis of review text, 3) Thematic analysis to identify common complaints, feature requests, and praises, 4) Comparison across app versions or platforms (iOS/Android), 5) Prioritization of issues based on frequency and severity.

title: SQL Query for Finding Duplicate Records
prompt: Act as a Data Quality Analyst. Write a SQL query to identify duplicate records in the table {{Table Name}} based on potential duplicate criteria across columns {{Column A}}, {{Column B}}, etc. Show how to list the duplicate rows or count the occurrences of each duplicated set.

title: Hyperparameter Tuning Strategy
prompt: Act as a Machine Learning Engineer. Describe strategies for hyperparameter tuning for a {{Model Type, e.g., Support Vector Machine, Neural Network}}. Compare methods like: 1) Grid Search, 2) Random Search, 3) Bayesian Optimization. Discuss the pros and cons of each in terms of computational cost and effectiveness. Mention the importance of using cross-validation during tuning.

title: Creating a Self-Service BI Environment
prompt: Act as a BI Manager. Outline the key components and considerations for creating a successful self-service BI environment for business users in {{Department}}. Include: 1) Defining curated and certified datasets, 2) Choosing user-friendly BI tools, 3) Providing adequate training and documentation, 4) Establishing data governance and security protocols, 5) Fostering a data-driven culture and providing support.

title: Analyzing Call Center Data
prompt: Act as an Operations Analyst. Analyze call center data {{Data Description, including metrics like call volume, AHT, FCR, CSAT}} to identify areas for operational improvement. Include analysis of: 1) Call volume patterns (time of day, day of week), 2) Agent performance variations, 3) Relationship between AHT/FCR and CSAT, 4) Common reasons for calls, 5) Potential bottlenecks or inefficiencies.

title: Interpreting Regression Coefficients
prompt: Act as a Statistician. Explain how to interpret the coefficients from a linear regression model: `Y = b0 + b1*X1 + b2*X2 + ...`. Explain the meaning of: 1) The intercept (b0), 2) The coefficient for a continuous predictor (e.g., b1), 3) The coefficient for a categorical predictor (dummy variable), 4) Considerations like units and statistical significance.

title: Data Analysis Ethics Checklist
prompt: Act as an AI Ethics Advisor. Create a checklist of ethical considerations for data analysts to review before starting a project involving {{Data Type, e.g., user data, sensitive information}}. Include points on: 1) Data privacy and consent, 2) Potential for bias in data or algorithms, 3) Transparency of methods, 4) Potential societal impact, 5) Security of data handling, 6) Clarity in reporting limitations.

title: Meeting Efficiency Audit
prompt: Act as a Productivity Consultant. Design a framework to audit the efficiency of recurring meetings like {{Meeting Name}}. Include criteria for evaluating: 1) Necessity of the meeting, 2) Clarity of agenda and objectives, 3) Attendee relevance and engagement, 4) Time management during the meeting, 5) Action item tracking and follow-through. Provide a scoring system and recommendations.

title: Email Management Strategy (Inbox Zero)
prompt: Act as an Email Productivity Expert. Outline a step-by-step strategy to achieve and maintain 'Inbox Zero' for someone dealing with {{Approximate number}} emails daily. Include: 1) Processing rules (e.g., Delete, Delegate, Respond, Defer, Do), 2) Folder/labeling system setup, 3) Techniques for reducing incoming email, 4) Scheduling specific times for email processing, 5) Tools or features to leverage (filters, templates).

title: Personalized Pomodoro Timer Setup
prompt: Act as a Time Management Coach. Help me personalize the Pomodoro Technique for {{Type of work, e.g., coding, writing, studying}}. Recommend: 1) Optimal work interval length based on task type, 2) Effective short break activities, 3) Ideal long break duration and frequency, 4) Strategies for handling interruptions during a Pomodoro, 5) Tools or apps for tracking Pomodoros.

title: Delegation Decision Matrix
prompt: Act as a Management Consultant. Create a decision matrix to help {{Role, e.g., a team lead, a manager}} decide which tasks to delegate. Include criteria such as: 1) Task importance vs. urgency, 2) Required skill level vs. team member capability, 3) Developmental opportunity for the team member, 4) Time availability of the delegator vs. delegatee, 5) Risk associated with delegation.

title: Digital Decluttering Plan
prompt: Act as a Digital Organization Expert. Create a 7-day plan to declutter digital files and systems for someone using {{Operating System, e.g., Windows, macOS}}. Include daily tasks focusing on: 1) Desktop cleanup, 2) Document folder organization, 3) Cloud storage optimization, 4) Email inbox management, 5) Browser bookmark cleanup, 6) Software/app removal, 7) Backup strategy review.

title: Weekly Review and Planning Process
prompt: Act as a Productivity Planner. Outline a structured weekly review and planning process based on Getting Things Done (GTD) principles. Include steps for: 1) Clearing inboxes (physical, digital), 2) Reviewing completed tasks and calendar, 3) Updating project lists and next actions, 4) Reviewing 'Waiting For' and 'Someday/Maybe' lists, 5) Defining goals and priorities for the upcoming week.

title: Morning Routine Design for Focus
prompt: Act as a Performance Coach. Design an ideal morning routine lasting {{Duration, e.g., 60 minutes}} specifically to enhance focus and productivity for {{Type of work day, e.g., a creative work day, a day with many meetings}}. Include elements like: 1) Hydration, 2) Mindful activity (meditation, journaling), 3) Light physical activity, 4) Planning/prioritizing the day's tasks, 5) Limiting early digital distractions.

title: Evening Shutdown Ritual
prompt: Act as a Work-Life Balance Coach. Create an 'end-of-workday' shutdown ritual to help disconnect from work and transition into personal time. Include steps like: 1) Reviewing tasks completed and planning for tomorrow, 2) Organizing workspace, 3) Closing unnecessary tabs and applications, 4) A specific 'transition' activity (e.g., short walk, listening to music), 5) Setting boundaries for checking work communication.

title: Prioritization using Eisenhower Matrix
prompt: Act as a Productivity Expert. Explain the Eisenhower Matrix (Urgent/Important) and guide me in applying it to prioritize my current task list: {{List of tasks or link to task list}}. Help categorize each task into one of the four quadrants (Do, Decide, Delegate, Delete) and suggest how to handle tasks in each quadrant.

title: Combating Procrastination Techniques
prompt: Act as a Behavioral Coach. Provide a list of actionable techniques to combat procrastination when facing {{Type of task, e.g., a large project, a difficult report}}. Include strategies like: 1) Breaking down the task (salami slicing), 2) The 5-Minute Rule, 3) Timeboxing, 4) Identifying and addressing the root cause (fear, perfectionism), 5) Setting up accountability.

title: Optimizing Workspace for Ergonomics
prompt: Act as an Ergonomics Consultant. Provide recommendations for optimizing a {{Type of workspace, e.g., home office desk, standing desk}} setup to improve comfort and reduce strain. Include advice on: 1) Chair height and posture, 2) Monitor positioning (height, distance), 3) Keyboard and mouse placement, 4) Lighting considerations, 5) Importance of regular breaks and movement.

title: Note-Taking System for Meetings
prompt: Act as a Professional Organizer. Design an effective system for taking and organizing notes from {{Type of meetings, e.g., project status meetings, client calls}}. Include: 1) A standardized template (digital or analog) with sections for date, attendees, agenda items, discussion points, decisions, action items (with owners/deadlines), 2) Method for quick capture during the meeting, 3) Process for reviewing and processing notes afterwards, 4) Integration with task management systems.

title: Goal Setting with OKRs (Personal)
prompt: Act as a Performance Coach. Guide me in setting personal Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) for the next quarter related to {{Personal Goal Area, e.g., learning a new skill, improving fitness}}. Help define 1-2 ambitious Objectives and 3-4 measurable Key Results for each Objective. Ensure KR's are specific and trackable.

title: Managing Multiple Projects Simultaneously
prompt: Act as a Project Management Advisor. Provide strategies and tools for effectively managing multiple projects simultaneously, common in {{Role or Industry}}. Include techniques for: 1) Centralized task tracking, 2) Prioritization across projects, 3) Time blocking for different projects, 4) Consistent status reporting, 5) Managing stakeholder expectations for each project.

title: Reducing Digital Distractions
prompt: Act as a Digital Wellness Coach. Provide a comprehensive list of strategies to reduce digital distractions from {{Specific sources, e.g., smartphone notifications, social media, news websites}} during focused work periods. Include: 1) App/website blockers, 2) Notification management techniques, 3) Designated 'distraction' times, 4) Environment setup (phone placement), 5) Mindset shifts regarding FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out).

title: Brainstorming Session Facilitation Guide
prompt: Act as a Creative Facilitator. Design a guide for facilitating a 60-minute brainstorming session for a team of {{Number}} people on the topic: {{Brainstorming Topic}}. Include: 1) Pre-session preparation, 2) Icebreaker activity, 3) Specific brainstorming techniques (e.g., Round Robin, SCAMPER, Reverse Brainstorming), 4) Rules for the session (e.g., defer judgment), 5) Methods for capturing ideas, 6) Next steps for idea evaluation.

title: Generating Alternative Uses (Divergent Thinking)
prompt: Act as a Divergent Thinking Coach. Generate a list of at least 20 alternative, unconventional uses for a common object: {{Common Object, e.g., a brick, a paperclip, a tire}}. Encourage thinking beyond the obvious functions.

title: Developing a Fictional Character Profile
prompt: Act as a Novelist. Create a detailed character profile for a fictional character who is {{Brief Character Concept, e.g., a disillusioned detective in a futuristic city, a young baker discovering magic}}. Include sections for: 1) Physical appearance, 2) Personality traits (strengths/weaknesses), 3) Backstory and key life events, 4) Motivations and goals, 5) Internal and external conflicts, 6) Quirks and habits.

title: Mind Map for Story Plotting
prompt: Act as a Creative Writer. Create a mind map structure (text-based representation) for plotting a story based on the premise: {{Story Premise}}. Include branches for: 1) Main characters, 2) Setting details, 3) Inciting incident, 4) Rising action points (key conflicts/obstacles), 5) Climax, 6) Falling action, 7) Resolution, 8) Potential themes.

title: Visual Mood Board Elements
prompt: Act as a Visual Designer. Generate a list of descriptive elements and image ideas for a visual mood board representing the theme: {{Theme/Concept, e.g., 'Urban Decay & Hope', 'Minimalist Scandinavian Winter', 'Retro Futurism'}}. Include suggestions for: 1) Color palette, 2) Textures, 3) Key imagery/photography styles, 4) Typography styles, 5) Overall mood/feeling.

title: Songwriting Prompt: Object Inspiration
prompt: Act as a Songwriter. Write song lyrics (verse 1, chorus, verse 2) inspired by the object: {{Object Name, e.g., an old photograph, a broken compass, a rain-streaked window}}. Focus on the emotions, memories, or stories the object evokes. Specify a potential genre (e.g., folk, indie rock, blues).

title: World-Building: Unique Ecosystem
prompt: Act as a Fantasy World Builder. Describe a unique and fantastical ecosystem found in the world of {{Fictional World Name}}. Include details on: 1) Dominant flora (plants), 2) Unique fauna (creatures), 3) Environmental conditions (climate, geography), 4) How the elements interact (symbiosis, predation), 5) Any magical properties or resources found there.

title: Abstract Art Concept Generation
prompt: Act as an Abstract Artist. Generate three distinct concepts for an abstract painting based on the emotion: {{Emotion, e.g., Serenity, Anxiety, Joy}}. For each concept, describe: 1) Potential color palette, 2) Dominant shapes or forms, 3) Brushstroke techniques or textures, 4) Overall composition idea.

title: Reimagining a Fairy Tale
prompt: Act as a Storyteller. Reimagine the classic fairy tale {{Fairy Tale Name, e.g., Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood}} in a different setting or genre: {{New Setting/Genre, e.g., cyberpunk future, wild west, political thriller}}. Outline the key plot points and how the characters and themes are adapted.

title: Designing a Fictional Technology
prompt: Act as a Science Fiction Author. Design a piece of fictional technology called {{Technology Name}} for a story set in {{Time Period/Setting}}. Describe: 1) Its primary function, 2) How it works (briefly, can be speculative), 3) Its appearance, 4) Potential benefits and drawbacks/dangers, 5) How it impacts society or the characters.

title: Poetry Form Challenge: Haiku Series
prompt: Act as a Poet. Write a series of three Haikus (5-7-5 syllable structure) on the theme of {{Theme, e.g., Changing Seasons, City Sounds, Inner Peace}}.

title: Logo Design Concept Brief
prompt: Act as a Brand Strategist. Create a detailed brief for a graphic designer to create a logo for a fictional company: {{Company Name}}, which provides {{Service/Product}}. Include: 1) Brand values/personality, 2) Target audience, 3) Desired style (e.g., modern, vintage, playful), 4) Color preferences or exclusions, 5) Competitor logos to consider, 6) Required logo variations (e.g., icon, wordmark).

title: Improvisational Scene Starter
prompt: Act as an Improv Coach. Provide an engaging scene starter for two improvisers. Include: 1) The location, 2) The relationship between the characters, 3) An unusual object present, 4) The first line of dialogue for Character 1.

title: Creating a Unique Holiday Tradition
prompt: Act as a Creative Consultant. Invent a unique, fictional holiday tradition for a family or community celebrating {{Occasion, e.g., the first snowfall, the summer solstice}}. Describe: 1) The name of the tradition, 2) When and how it's celebrated, 3) Special foods, activities, or symbols involved, 4) The meaning or purpose behind it.

title: Generating 'What If' Scenarios
prompt: Act as a Speculative Fiction Writer. Generate five intriguing 'What If' scenarios based on altering a historical event: {{Historical Event}}. For each scenario, briefly explore the potential immediate consequences.

title: Applying TRIZ Principles
prompt: Act as an Innovation Consultant using TRIZ methodology. Analyze the technical contradiction in {{Problem Description, e.g., 'Need to increase strength of a material without increasing its weight'}}. Identify the conflicting parameters using the TRIZ contradiction matrix and suggest inventive principles that could lead to solutions.

title: Pre-Mortem Analysis for Project Risk
prompt: Act as a Risk Management Facilitator. Guide a team through a Pre-Mortem analysis for the upcoming project: {{Project Name}}. Ask the team to imagine the project has failed spectacularly and brainstorm all possible reasons for this failure. Categorize the potential failure points and identify preventative actions.

title: Developing an Issue Tree (Logic Tree)
prompt: Act as a Strategy Consultant. Structure an issue tree (logic tree) to break down the problem: {{Problem Statement, e.g., 'Declining profitability in Division X'}}. Start with the main problem and break it down into mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive (MECE) sub-components (e.g., Revenue issues vs. Cost issues), continuing for 2-3 levels.

title: Force Field Analysis for Change Initiative
prompt: Act as a Change Management Specialist. Conduct a Force Field Analysis for the proposed change: {{Change Initiative, e.g., 'Implementing a new CRM system'}}. Identify the driving forces supporting the change and the restraining forces opposing it. Assign a relative strength score to each force and suggest strategies to strengthen drivers and weaken restrainers.

title: Gap Analysis Framework
prompt: Act as a Performance Improvement Analyst. Outline a Gap Analysis framework to compare the current state with the desired future state for {{Process or Area, e.g., 'Customer onboarding process', 'Team skill levels'}}. Include steps for: 1) Defining the desired future state, 2) Assessing the current state, 3) Identifying the gaps, 4) Analyzing the root causes of the gaps, 5) Developing action plans to bridge the gaps.

title: Stakeholder Analysis Matrix
prompt: Act as a Project Manager. Create a Stakeholder Analysis Matrix for the project: {{Project Name}}. Identify key stakeholders and analyze them based on: 1) Their level of interest in the project, 2) Their level of influence/power over the project, 3) Their current stance (supporter, neutral, blocker), 4) Key needs/expectations, 5) Proposed engagement strategy.

title: Applying Occam's Razor
prompt: Act as a Critical Thinker. Given two competing explanations for {{Phenomenon or Problem, e.g., 'a sudden drop in website traffic', 'a system outage'}}: Explanation A: {{Explanation A}} and Explanation B: {{Explanation B}}. Apply Occam's Razor (the principle that the simplest explanation is usually the best) to evaluate which explanation is more likely, considering the assumptions each requires.

title: Cost-Benefit Analysis Framework
prompt: Act as a Financial Analyst. Outline a framework for conducting a Cost-Benefit Analysis for the proposed investment/project: {{Project/Investment Description}}. Include sections for: 1) Identifying and quantifying all potential costs (initial, ongoing), 2) Identifying and quantifying all potential benefits (tangible, intangible), 3) Choosing a time horizon and discount rate, 4) Calculating metrics like Net Present Value (NPV) and Benefit-Cost Ratio (BCR), 5) Sensitivity analysis.

title: Six Thinking Hats Exercise
prompt: Act as a Facilitator using De Bono's Six Thinking Hats. Structure an exercise for a group to evaluate the idea: {{Idea to Evaluate}}. Assign roles or time slots for each hat: White (Facts), Red (Emotions), Black (Caution/Risks), Yellow (Benefits/Optimism), Green (Creativity/Alternatives), Blue (Process Control). Provide guiding questions for each hat.

title: Scenario Planning for Uncertainty
prompt: Act as a Strategic Foresight Analyst. Develop 2-3 plausible future scenarios for {{Industry or Market}} facing uncertainty due to {{Key Uncertain Factors, e.g., technological disruption, regulatory changes}}. For each scenario: 1) Give it a descriptive name, 2) Describe the key characteristics of the world in that scenario, 3) Identify potential implications and challenges/opportunities for {{Your Organization}}.

title: Reframing a Problem Statement
prompt: Act as a Design Thinking Coach. The current problem statement is: {{Original Problem Statement}}. Reframe this problem statement from different perspectives to open up new solution possibilities. Try reframing it by: 1) Focusing on a different user, 2) Emphasizing a different aspect of the problem, 3) Making it more specific, 4) Making it broader.

title: Decision Journal Template
prompt: Act as a Decision Analyst. Create a template for a Decision Journal to improve decision-making skills. Include fields for: 1) Date, 2) The decision to be made, 3) Situation/Context, 4) Options considered, 5) Expected outcome(s) and probabilities, 6) Information available at the time, 7) The decision made and rationale, 8) Actual outcome (to be filled later), 9) Lessons learned.

title: Analogical Reasoning for Problem Solving
prompt: Act as an Innovation Strategist. Use analogical reasoning to find potential solutions for the problem: {{Problem Description}}. Identify analogous problems or situations in different domains (e.g., nature, other industries) where similar challenges have been overcome. Describe the analogous solution and how it might be adapted.

title: Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
prompt: Act as a Reliability Engineer. Outline the steps to conduct a Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) for {{Product or Process}}. Include: 1) Identifying potential failure modes, 2) Determining potential effects of each failure, 3) Identifying potential causes, 4) Assessing Severity, Occurrence, and Detection ratings, 5) Calculating Risk Priority Number (RPN), 6) Recommending actions for high-risk items.

title: Constraint Analysis (Theory of Constraints)
prompt: Act as an Operations Consultant using the Theory of Constraints. Analyze the process {{Process Description}} to identify the primary constraint (bottleneck). Outline the Five Focusing Steps: 1) Identify the constraint, 2) Exploit the constraint, 3) Subordinate everything else to the constraint, 4) Elevate the constraint, 5) Repeat the process (avoid inertia).

title: Generate Unit Tests (Python)
prompt: Act as a Python Developer. Write unit tests using the `unittest` or `pytest` framework for the following Python function: {{Python Function Code Snippet}}. Include tests for: 1) Happy path scenarios, 2) Edge cases (e.g., empty input, zero values), 3) Potential error conditions (e.g., invalid input types).

title: Refactor JavaScript for Async/Await
prompt: Act as a JavaScript Developer. Refactor the following JavaScript code, which uses Promise `.then()` syntax, to use `async/await` for better readability: {{JavaScript Promise Code Snippet}}.

title: Explain Python List Comprehension
prompt: Act as a Python Tutor. Explain the concept of list comprehensions in Python. Provide a simple example of a `for` loop creating a list and show how to achieve the same result using a list comprehension. Include an example with a conditional statement.

title: Create SQL Table Schema
prompt: Act as a Database Designer. Write the SQL `CREATE TABLE` statement for a table named `{{Table Name}}` to store information about {{Data Description}}. Include appropriate column names, data types (e.g., VARCHAR, INT, DATE, BOOLEAN), primary key constraint, and any necessary foreign key constraints or NOT NULL constraints.

title: Implement Basic REST API Endpoint (Node.js/Express)
prompt: Act as a Node.js Developer. Write a basic Express.js route handler for a `GET` request to the endpoint `/api/{{resource}}/:id`. The handler should retrieve the `id` parameter from the request, query a hypothetical database/data source for the resource, and return the resource as JSON or a 404 error if not found.

title: CSS Flexbox Layout Example
prompt: Act as a Frontend Developer. Provide HTML and CSS code using Flexbox to create a layout with {{Description of Layout, e.g., 'a header, a main content area, and a footer stacked vertically', 'three equal-width columns side-by-side'}}.

title: Git Workflow Explanation (Feature Branch)
prompt: Act as a DevOps Engineer. Explain the standard Git feature branch workflow. Include the steps: 1) Creating a new branch from `main`/`develop`, 2) Making changes and committing locally, 3) Pushing the feature branch to the remote repository, 4) Opening a Pull Request (PR) or Merge Request (MR), 5) Code review and discussion, 6) Merging the branch.

title: Implement Sorting Algorithm (e.g., Bubble Sort)
prompt: Act as a Computer Science Student. Implement the {{Sorting Algorithm Name, e.g., Bubble Sort, Insertion Sort}} algorithm in {{Programming Language, e.g., Python, Java}}. Include comments explaining the logic of the algorithm.

title: Handling Errors in Go
prompt: Act as a Go Developer. Explain the standard way of handling errors in Go using the `error` interface. Provide a code example of a function that returns both a value and an error, and show how the calling code should check and handle the potential error.

title: Dockerize a Simple Web Application
prompt: Act as a DevOps Engineer. Create a simple `Dockerfile` to containerize a basic {{Language/Framework, e.g., Python Flask, Node.js Express}} web application. The Dockerfile should: 1) Specify a base image, 2) Copy application code, 3) Install dependencies, 4) Expose the necessary port, 5) Define the command to run the application.

title: Object-Oriented Programming Concepts
prompt: Act as a Software Engineering Instructor. Explain the four fundamental concepts of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP): 1) Encapsulation, 2) Abstraction, 3) Inheritance, 4) Polymorphism. Provide a brief definition and a simple real-world analogy for each concept.

title: Regular Expression for Validation
prompt: Act as a Software Developer. Write a regular expression to validate {{Type of Input, e.g., a strong password (min 8 chars, upper, lower, digit, symbol), a North American phone number, a date in YYYY-MM-DD format}}. Explain the components of the regex.

title: Basic HTML Form Structure
prompt: Act as a Web Developer. Create the basic HTML structure for a form that collects {{Form Data, e.g., user registration (username, email, password), contact information (name, email, message)}}. Include appropriate input types, labels, and a submit button.

title: Data Structures: Linked List vs Array
prompt: Act as a Computer Scientist. Compare and contrast Linked Lists and Arrays as data structures. Discuss their differences in terms of: 1) Memory allocation, 2) Insertion/Deletion performance (beginning, middle, end), 3) Access time, 4) Use cases where one might be preferred over the other.

title: JSON Data Parsing (Python)
prompt: Act as a Python Developer. Show how to parse a JSON string or file in Python using the `json` module. Provide code examples for: 1) Loading JSON from a string (`json.loads()`), 2) Loading JSON from a file (`json.load()`), 3) Accessing data within the parsed JSON object.

title: Elevator Pitch for Startup
prompt: Act as an Entrepreneur. Craft a compelling 30-60 second elevator pitch for a startup called {{Startup Name}} that provides {{Product/Service}} targeting {{Target Market}}. The pitch should clearly state the problem, solution, target market, and unique value proposition.

title: SWOT Analysis for {{Company/Product}}
prompt: Act as a Business Analyst. Conduct a SWOT analysis for {{Company Name or Product}}. Identify and list key: 1) Strengths (internal, positive), 2) Weaknesses (internal, negative), 3) Opportunities (external, positive), 4) Threats (external, negative).

title: Meeting Agenda Template
prompt: Act as an Administrative Professional. Create a reusable meeting agenda template for {{Type of Meeting, e.g., weekly team meeting, project kick-off}}. Include sections for: 1) Meeting objective, 2) Date, time, location, attendees, 3) Review of previous action items, 4) Agenda topics with time allocation and lead person, 5) New action items, 6) Next steps/meeting.

title: Business Model Canvas Outline
prompt: Act as a Business Strategist. Outline the 9 building blocks of the Business Model Canvas for a business idea: {{Business Idea Description}}. List the key questions or elements to consider for each block: 1) Customer Segments, 2) Value Propositions, 3) Channels, 4) Customer Relationships, 5) Revenue Streams, 6) Key Resources, 7) Key Activities, 8) Key Partnerships, 9) Cost Structure.

title: Professional Email for {{Purpose}}
prompt: Act as a Business Communication Specialist. Draft a professional email for the purpose of {{Purpose, e.g., requesting an informational interview, following up after a meeting, introducing two contacts}}. Ensure the email has a clear subject line, polite tone, concise body, and a clear call to action or closing.

title: Job Description for {{Role}}
prompt: Act as an HR Manager. Write a job description for the role of {{Job Title}} at {{Company Type, e.g., a tech startup, a non-profit organization}}. Include sections for: 1) Job summary, 2) Key responsibilities, 3) Required qualifications (skills, experience, education), 4) Preferred qualifications, 5) Company overview and culture.

title: Competitive Analysis Summary
prompt: Act as a Market Analyst. Provide a brief competitive analysis summary comparing {{Your Company/Product}} with its top 2-3 competitors: {{Competitor Names}}. Focus on key differentiating factors such as: 1) Target market, 2) Key features/offerings, 3) Pricing strategy, 4) Perceived strengths and weaknesses.

title: Project Proposal Outline
prompt: Act as a Project Manager. Create an outline for a project proposal to {{Stakeholder, e.g., management, a client}} for the project: {{Project Description}}. Include sections for: 1) Introduction/Problem Statement, 2) Proposed Solution/Project Goals, 3) Scope of Work, 4) Deliverables, 5) Timeline/Milestones, 6) Required Resources/Budget, 7) Expected Benefits/ROI.

title: Value Proposition Statement
prompt: Act as a Marketing Strategist. Craft a clear and concise value proposition statement for {{Product/Service}}. Use the format: 'For [target customer] who [statement of need/opportunity], our [product/service] is a [product category] that [statement of benefit/key differentiator].'

title: Negotiation Preparation Checklist
prompt: Act as a Negotiation Coach. Create a checklist to prepare for an upcoming business negotiation regarding {{Negotiation Topic}}. Include items like: 1) Define objectives (ideal, acceptable, walk-away points), 2) Research counterparty and context, 3) Identify your BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement), 4) Brainstorm potential issues and concessions, 5) Plan opening strategy and key arguments.

title: Simple Budget Template (Small Business)
prompt: Act as a Small Business Advisor. Create a simple monthly budget template for a small business like {{Business Type}}. Include categories for: 1) Revenue Streams (estimated), 2) Cost of Goods Sold (COGS), 3) Operating Expenses (Rent, Utilities, Salaries, Marketing, Supplies, etc.), 4) Calculation of Gross Profit and Net Profit.

title: Performance Review Feedback Phrases
prompt: Act as an HR Manager. Provide examples of constructive feedback phrases for a performance review, covering areas like: 1) Communication skills (Positive & Needs Improvement), 2) Teamwork (Positive & Needs Improvement), 3) Problem-solving (Positive & Needs Improvement), 4) Meeting goals (Exceeds, Meets, Needs Improvement).

title: Risk Management Plan Outline
prompt: Act as a Risk Manager. Outline the key sections of a Risk Management Plan for {{Project or Business Area}}. Include: 1) Introduction/Scope, 2) Risk Identification methods, 3) Risk Analysis (likelihood, impact), 4) Risk Register template (Risk description, Cause, Effect, Likelihood, Impact, Response Plan, Owner), 5) Risk Response Strategies (Avoid, Mitigate, Transfer, Accept), 6) Monitoring and Reporting.

title: Client Onboarding Checklist
prompt: Act as an Account Manager. Create a checklist for onboarding a new client for {{Type of Service, e.g., a marketing agency, a SaaS product}}. Include steps like: 1) Contract signing and payment processing, 2) Kick-off meeting scheduling, 3) Information gathering (requirements, access), 4) Setting up accounts/tools, 5) Introduction to the team, 6) Defining communication plan and success metrics.

title: Executive Summary for Business Plan
prompt: Act as a Business Plan Writer. Write a concise Executive Summary (approx. 1-2 pages) for a fictional business plan for {{Startup Name}} providing {{Product/Service}}. Cover the key points: 1) Mission/Vision, 2) Problem & Solution, 3) Target Market, 4) Business Model/Revenue, 5) Team, 6) Competitive Advantage, 7) Financial Projections (summary), 8) Funding Request (if applicable).

title: Social Media Content Calendar (Weekly)
prompt: Act as a Social Media Manager. Create a sample weekly content calendar template for promoting {{Product/Service}} on {{Platform 1, e.g., Instagram}} and {{Platform 2, e.g., LinkedIn}}. Include columns for: Day, Platform, Content Type (e.g., image, video, article link, poll), Caption/Copy, Hashtags, Goal (e.g., engagement, traffic). Fill in 2-3 sample posts.

title: Blog Post Ideas for {{Topic}}
prompt: Act as a Content Marketer. Generate 10 blog post ideas (titles) related to the topic {{Topic, e.g., 'sustainable living', 'small business cybersecurity', 'healthy eating on a budget'}}. Ensure the titles are engaging and target potential search queries.

title: Email Subject Line A/B Test
prompt: Act as an Email Marketing Specialist. Write two different subject lines (A and B) for an email promoting {{Offer/Content, e.g., a 20% discount, a new webinar}}. Subject Line A should focus on {{Angle A, e.g., urgency, benefit}}, and Subject Line B should focus on {{Angle B, e.g., curiosity, personalization}}. Explain the hypothesis for the test.

title: Target Audience Persona
prompt: Act as a Marketing Researcher. Create a detailed target audience persona for a customer interested in {{Product/Service}}. Include: 1) Fictional Name & Photo Description, 2) Demographics (Age, Location, Occupation, Income), 3) Psychographics (Values, Interests, Lifestyle), 4) Goals & Challenges (related to the product), 5) Pain Points, 6) Preferred Communication Channels, 7) How the product helps them.

title: Call to Action (CTA) Variations
prompt: Act as a Copywriter. Write 5 different Call to Action (CTA) button texts for a landing page offering {{Offer, e.g., a free trial, an ebook download, a consultation}}. Vary the CTAs in terms of length, benefit focus, and urgency.

title: SEO Keyword Research Strategy
prompt: Act as an SEO Specialist. Outline a strategy for conducting keyword research for a website selling {{Product Type, e.g., handmade jewelry, online courses}}. Include steps for: 1) Identifying seed keywords, 2) Using keyword research tools (mention types, e.g., Google Keyword Planner, SEMrush), 3) Analyzing keyword metrics (volume, difficulty, intent), 4) Identifying long-tail keywords, 5) Competitor keyword analysis.

title: Unique Selling Proposition (USP) Development
prompt: Act as a Brand Strategist. Help develop a Unique Selling Proposition (USP) for {{Company/Product}} in the {{Industry}} market. Guide the process by asking questions about: 1) Target audience needs, 2) Competitor offerings, 3) The product's unique features/benefits, 4) What makes it stand out? Draft 2-3 potential USP statements.

title: Influencer Marketing Brief
prompt: Act as a Marketing Manager. Create a brief for an influencer to promote {{Product Name}}. Include: 1) Campaign objectives, 2) Target audience, 3) Key message points to convey, 4) Content requirements (e.g., Instagram post, YouTube video, story mentions), 5) Dos and Don'ts, 6) Disclosure requirements (#ad), 7) Timeline and compensation.

title: Landing Page Copy Outline
prompt: Act as a Conversion Copywriter. Create an outline for the copy of a landing page designed to {{Landing Page Goal, e.g., generate leads for a SaaS product, sell tickets to an event}}. Include sections for: 1) Headline (compelling, benefit-driven), 2) Sub-headline (clarification), 3) Problem/Pain Point description, 4) Solution/Product description, 5) Key Features/Benefits (bullet points), 6) Social Proof (testimonials, logos), 7) Call to Action.

title: Google Ads Campaign Structure
prompt: Act as a PPC Specialist. Outline a recommended Google Ads campaign structure for a business selling {{Product/Service Category, e.g., running shoes, plumbing services}}. Include: 1) Campaign goals (e.g., sales, leads), 2) Proposed campaign types (e.g., Search, Display), 3) Ad Group themes based on keywords, 4) Examples of keyword match types, 5) Ad copy considerations.

title: Customer Journey Map Outline
prompt: Act as a Customer Experience Designer. Outline the stages and key elements of a customer journey map for someone purchasing {{Product/Service Type}}. Include stages like: 1) Awareness, 2) Consideration, 3) Decision/Purchase, 4) Onboarding/Use, 5) Loyalty/Advocacy. For each stage, consider: Customer Actions, Touchpoints, Thoughts/Feelings, Pain Points, Opportunities.

title: Content Promotion Checklist
prompt: Act as a Content Marketing Manager. Create a checklist for promoting a newly published piece of content (e.g., blog post, case study) titled {{Content Title}}. Include promotion channels/tactics like: 1) Email newsletter, 2) Social media platforms (organic), 3) Social media advertising, 4) Outreach to influencers/partners, 5) Repurposing content (e.g., video, infographic), 6) Internal promotion.

title: Marketing Budget Allocation Proposal
prompt: Act as a Marketing Director. Propose a marketing budget allocation for a {{Time Period, e.g., quarter, year}} with a total budget of {{Total Budget Amount}}. Allocate percentages or amounts across key channels/activities like: 1) Content Marketing, 2) SEO, 3) Paid Search (PPC), 4) Social Media Marketing (Organic & Paid), 5) Email Marketing, 6) Events/PR. Justify the allocation based on {{Business Goals}}.

title: Video Marketing Script Outline (Explainer)
prompt: Act as a Video Scriptwriter. Create an outline for a short (60-90 second) explainer video about {{Product/Service}}. Include sections for: 1) Hook (problem statement), 2) Introduction of the solution, 3) How it works (key steps/features), 4) Key benefits, 5) Social proof/testimonial (optional), 6) Call to Action.

title: Measuring Marketing Campaign Success
prompt: Act as a Marketing Analyst. Define key metrics to measure the success of a marketing campaign aimed at {{Campaign Goal, e.g., increasing brand awareness, generating leads}}. Include metrics related to: 1) Reach/Impressions, 2) Engagement (clicks, likes, shares), 3) Website Traffic, 4) Conversions (leads, sales), 5) Cost per Acquisition (CPA) or Return on Ad Spend (ROAS).

title: Explaining Complex Topic with ELI5
prompt: Act as a Teacher using the ELI5 (Explain Like I'm 5) technique. Explain the complex topic {{Complex Topic, e.g., Blockchain, General Relativity, Photosynthesis}} in extremely simple terms, using analogies and avoiding jargon, as if explaining it to a curious 5-year-old.

title: Creating a Study Schedule for {{Exam}}
prompt: Act as an Academic Advisor. Help create a realistic weekly study schedule for a student preparing for the {{Exam Name}} covering {{Subjects}}. The student has {{Number}} weeks left and can study {{Hours}} hours per week. Allocate time for each subject, practice tests, and revision. Include buffer time.

title: Active Recall Questions for {{Chapter/Topic}}
prompt: Act as a Study Coach. Generate 10-15 active recall questions based on the key concepts covered in {{Chapter Name or Topic Description}}. The questions should require retrieving information from memory, not just recognition (e.g., 'Explain X', 'Compare Y and Z', 'What are the steps in process A?').

title: Spaced Repetition System (SRS) Explanation
prompt: Act as a Learning Scientist. Explain the principle of Spaced Repetition for efficient memorization. Describe how SRS software (like Anki, Quizlet) works by scheduling reviews of flashcards at increasing intervals based on recall success. Discuss the benefits for long-term retention.

title: Identifying Reliable Sources for Research
prompt: Act as a Librarian or Research Assistant. Provide criteria for evaluating the reliability and credibility of sources when researching {{Topic}}. Discuss factors like: 1) Author expertise and credentials, 2) Publication type (peer-reviewed journal, reputable news source, blog), 3) Publication date (currency), 4) Bias and objectivity, 5) Citations and references.

title: Mind Palace (Method of Loci) Guide
prompt: Act as a Memory Champion. Provide a step-by-step guide on how to use the Mind Palace (Method of Loci) technique to memorize {{List of Items, e.g., a shopping list, key historical dates, steps in a process}}. Include: 1) Choosing a familiar location, 2) Creating vivid mental images for each item, 3) Placing the images along a route in the location, 4) Mentally walking the route to recall items.

title: Concept Map for {{Scientific Process}}
prompt: Act as a Science Educator. Create a text-based representation of a concept map illustrating the key stages, inputs, and outputs of the scientific process: {{Scientific Process, e.g., Photosynthesis, Cellular Respiration, The Water Cycle}}. Show the relationships between concepts using linking phrases.

title: Learning Path for {{Software Skill}}
prompt: Act as a Technical Trainer. Outline a structured learning path for a beginner to acquire proficiency in {{Software Skill, e.g., Advanced Excel Formulas, Basic Video Editing with Adobe Premiere Pro, Version Control with Git}}. Break it down into modules or stages, suggesting key concepts/features to learn in order and potential practice exercises.

title: Summarizing Lecture Notes Effectively
prompt: Act as an Academic Skills Tutor. Provide techniques for effectively summarizing lecture notes after a class on {{Subject}}. Include methods like: 1) Identifying main ideas and supporting details, 2) Using keywords and abbreviations, 3) Rewriting concepts in one's own words, 4) Creating visual summaries (mind maps, outlines), 5) Formulating potential exam questions.

title: Practice Problems for {{Math Concept}}
prompt: Act as a Math Teacher. Create 5 practice problems of varying difficulty for the mathematical concept: {{Math Concept, e.g., Solving Linear Equations, Calculating Area of Circles, Basic Probability}}. Include the solutions.

title: Applying Deliberate Practice
prompt: Act as a Performance Psychologist. Explain the principles of Deliberate Practice and how to apply them to improve the skill of {{Skill, e.g., playing a musical instrument, coding, public speaking}}. Include: 1) Setting specific, challenging goals, 2) Focused attention and effort, 3) Immediate and informative feedback, 4) Repetition and refinement.

title: Glossary of Terms for {{Field}}
prompt: Act as a Subject Matter Expert. Create a glossary of 10-15 key terms and their definitions relevant to the field of {{Field of Study, e.g., Artificial Intelligence, Macroeconomics, Molecular Biology}}. Ensure definitions are clear and concise for a beginner.

title: Using Analogies to Understand {{Abstract Concept}}
prompt: Act as an Educator. Develop 2-3 helpful analogies to explain the abstract concept of {{Abstract Concept, e.g., Compound Interest, Recursion in programming, Cognitive Dissonance}}. For each analogy, explain the mapping and potential limitations.

title: Self-Correction Checklist for Writing
prompt: Act as a Writing Instructor. Create a self-correction checklist for students to use when reviewing their own writing (e.g., essays, reports). Include checks for: 1) Clarity of thesis/main idea, 2) Logical flow and organization, 3) Strength of evidence/support, 4) Grammar and punctuation errors, 5) Sentence structure variety, 6) Word choice and tone.

title: Finding a Mentor for {{Skill/Career}}
prompt: Act as a Career Advisor. Provide advice and steps for finding a mentor in the field of {{Skill or Career Area}}. Include tips on: 1) Identifying potential mentors, 2) Crafting a respectful outreach message, 3) Preparing for an initial conversation, 4) Nurturing the mentor-mentee relationship, 5) Being a good mentee.

title: Python Pandas Data Cleaning Script
prompt: Act as a Data Analyst using Python. Write a Python script using pandas to perform common data cleaning tasks on a DataFrame loaded from `{{filename.csv}}`. Include steps for: 1) Handling missing values (e.g., filling with mean/median, dropping rows/columns), 2) Correcting data types, 3) Removing duplicate rows, 4) Renaming columns.

title: SQL Query for Customer Segmentation (RFM)
prompt: Act as a SQL Analyst. Write a SQL query using CTEs and window functions to calculate Recency, Frequency, and Monetary (RFM) scores for customers based on a `transactions` table (`customer_id`, `transaction_date`, `amount`). Assign scores (e.g., 1-5) based on quintiles and output the customer ID with their R, F, and M scores.

title: Interpreting A/B Test Results with Confidence Intervals
prompt: Act as a Data Scientist. An A/B test resulted in: Control Group ({{N_control}} users, {{Conversions_control}} conversions) and Variant Group ({{N_variant}} users, {{Conversions_variant}} conversions). Calculate the conversion rates for both groups, the difference in conversion rates, and the 95% confidence interval for the difference. Interpret the results and state whether the difference is statistically significant.

title: Choosing Metrics for {{Business Model}} Dashboard
prompt: Act as a BI Consultant. Recommend key performance indicators (KPIs) and supporting metrics for a dashboard monitoring a {{Business Model, e.g., SaaS subscription, E-commerce, Lead Generation}} business. Categorize metrics (e.g., Acquisition, Engagement, Retention, Revenue) and explain why each is important.

title: Time Series Decomposition Plot (Python)
prompt: Act as a Data Scientist using Python. Write Python code using `statsmodels` or a similar library to perform time series decomposition (trend, seasonal, residual) on the time series data {{Data Description or Variable Name}} loaded into a pandas DataFrame. Generate plots for the original series and its components.

title: Validating Assumptions of Linear Regression
prompt: Act as a Statistician. Explain the key assumptions of linear regression (Linearity, Independence, Homoscedasticity, Normality of residuals - LINE). Describe how to check each assumption using diagnostic plots (e.g., residuals vs. fitted, Q-Q plot) or statistical tests after fitting a model.

title: Calculating Net Promoter Score (NPS) in SQL
prompt: Act as a SQL Analyst. Write a SQL query to calculate the Net Promoter Score (NPS) from a `survey_responses` table containing `user_id` and `nps_score` (0-10). The query should categorize scores into Detractors (0-6), Passives (7-8), Promoters (9-10), calculate the percentage of each, and compute the final NPS.

title: Feature Importance Plot (Python)
prompt: Act as a Machine Learning Engineer using Python. After training a tree-based model (e.g., RandomForestClassifier, GradientBoostingClassifier) stored in the variable `model`, write Python code using libraries like `scikit-learn` and `matplotlib`/`seaborn` to extract and plot the feature importances.

title: Designing a Data Quality Dashboard
prompt: Act as a Data Governance Analyst. Design the layout and key metrics for a Data Quality Dashboard monitoring the dataset {{Dataset Name}}. Include visualizations/KPIs for: 1) Completeness (null rates per column), 2) Uniqueness (duplicate counts), 3) Validity (conformance to formats/ranges), 4) Timeliness (data latency), 5) Consistency (across related tables).

title: Handling Imbalanced Data in Classification
prompt: Act as a Machine Learning Specialist. Discuss strategies for handling imbalanced datasets when training a classification model for {{Problem, e.g., fraud detection, disease prediction}} where the positive class is rare. Compare techniques like: 1) Resampling (Oversampling - SMOTE, Undersampling), 2) Using different evaluation metrics (Precision, Recall, F1, AUC-PR), 3) Cost-sensitive learning, 4) Anomaly detection approaches.

title: SQL Query for Calculating Running Total
prompt: Act as a SQL Developer. Write a SQL query using window functions to calculate the running total of {{Metric Column, e.g., sales_amount}} partitioned by {{Partition Column, e.g., category}} and ordered by {{Date Column}} in the table {{Table Name}}.

title: Explaining p-value and Statistical Significance
prompt: Act as a Statistics Tutor. Explain the concept of a p-value in hypothesis testing. Describe what a p-value represents, how it's used with a significance level (alpha) to make a decision, and common misinterpretations to avoid (e.g., p-value is NOT the probability the null hypothesis is true).

title: Creating Interactive Map Visualization (Python)
prompt: Act as a Geospatial Analyst using Python. Write Python code using libraries like `folium` or `plotly.express` to create an interactive map visualizing {{Data Description, e.g., store locations with sales data, earthquake magnitudes}}. The map should include markers, popups with information, and potentially layers or color-coding based on data values.

title: Defining Metrics for A/B Testing {{Feature}}
prompt: Act as a Product Analyst. Define primary and secondary metrics for an A/B test evaluating the impact of launching {{New Feature or Change}} on {{Platform/Product}}. Include metrics related to: 1) Direct engagement with the feature, 2) Overall user engagement, 3) Conversion goals, 4) Potential negative impacts (guardrail metrics).

title: ETL Job Failure Troubleshooting
prompt: Act as a Data Engineer. An ETL job loading data from {{Source}} to {{Target}} failed with the error message: {{Error Message}}. Outline the steps you would take to troubleshoot the failure. Include checking: 1) Source system connectivity/availability, 2) Data format/schema validation, 3) Transformation logic errors, 4) Target system capacity/permissions, 5) Job logs for specific details.

title: Automated Meeting Minutes Generator
prompt: Act as a Productivity Tool Designer. Design a system that integrates with {{Calendar App}} and {{Video Conferencing Tool}} to automatically generate meeting minutes. Include features like: 1) Speaker identification, 2) Action item detection and assignment, 3) Key decision summarization, 4) Transcript generation, 5) Integration with task management tools like {{Task Management Tool}}.

title: Podcast Advertising Strategy
prompt: Act as a Podcast Marketing Specialist. Develop an advertising strategy to promote {{Product/Service}} on relevant podcasts. Include: 1) Identifying target podcast genres and specific shows, 2) Defining ad formats (pre-roll, mid-roll, host-read), 3) Crafting compelling ad scripts, 4) Setting budget and measuring ROI (e.g., using promo codes, vanity URLs), 5) Negotiating rates with podcasters.

Cover concepts like input layer, hidden layers, output layer, weights, and activation functions in very simple terms.

title: Troubleshooting Cloud Resource Misconfiguration
prompt: Act as a Cloud Engineer. A cloud resource (e.g., {{Cloud Service like EC2 instance, S3 bucket}}) in {{Cloud Provider like AWS, Azure, GCP}} is behaving unexpectedly: {{Symptom}}. Outline troubleshooting steps focusing on misconfiguration: 1) Reviewing resource configuration settings, 2) Checking security groups/firewall rules, 3) Verifying IAM permissions/roles, 4) Examining relevant logs (e.g., CloudTrail, CloudWatch), 5) Comparing configuration against best practices or previous working state.

title: Character Arc Development

Describe their: 1) Initial state (flaw, goal, worldview), 2) Inciting incident impact, 3) Key challenges/trials that force change, 4) Midpoint shift/realization, 5) Climax decision/action demonstrating change, 6) Final transformed state.

prompt: Act as an Agile Coach. Guide me in setting up a personal Kanban board (physical or digital using {{Tool like Trello, Asana}}) to manage my tasks for {{Work Type or Project}}. Define columns (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done), Work-in-Progress (WIP) limits, and how to use it for daily planning and workflow visualization.

prompt: Act as an Affiliate Marketing Manager. Design an affiliate program for {{Product/Service}}. Include: 1) Commission structure (e.g., percentage per sale, flat fee per lead), 2) Cookie duration, 3) Affiliate approval criteria, 4) Promotional materials to provide (banners, links, swipe copy), 5) Payout terms and schedule, 6) Tracking platform selection.

title: Creating Mnemonics for {{Subject}}
prompt: Act as a Memory Aid Creator. Develop 3-5 memorable mnemonic devices (e.g., acronyms, acrostics, rhymes, imagery) to help remember key facts or lists related to {{Specific Subject Topic, e.g., the order of planets, taxonomic ranks, musical notes on a staff}}.

Include: 1) Identifying conflicting files (`git status`), 2) Opening files to view conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>), 3) Editing files to keep desired changes, 4) Staging resolved files (`git add`), 5) Completing the merge (`git merge --continue` or `git commit`).

title: Generating Metaphors for {{Concept}}
prompt: Act as a Poet or Copywriter. Generate 5 original metaphors to describe the abstract concept of {{Abstract Concept, e.g., 'creativity', 'time', 'freedom', 'memory'}}. Explain the connection briefly for each.

Suggest specific batches (e.g., 'Email Power Hour', 'Meeting Block') and explain how batching reduces context switching and improves efficiency.

title: Public Relations (PR) Pitch Angle
prompt: Act as a PR Specialist. Develop 3 compelling pitch angles to secure media coverage for {{Company/Product/Event}}. For each angle, identify: 1) The target media outlet/journalist type, 2) The core story hook, 3) Why it's relevant/timely now, 4) Key supporting facts or data.

title: Applying the Feynman Technique
prompt: Act as a Learning Coach. Guide me in applying the Feynman Technique to deeply understand the topic: {{Topic to Learn}}. Walk me through the steps: 1) Choose the concept, 2) Explain it simply (as if to a child), 3) Identify knowledge gaps during explanation, 4) Review source material to fill gaps, 5) Simplify and refine the explanation using analogies.

prompt: Act as an Experimentation Analyst. Formulate a clear, testable hypothesis for an A/B test designed to improve {{Metric, e.g., click-through rate on a button, sign-up conversion rate}} by changing {{Element being changed, e.g., button color, headline text}}. Use the format: 'If we [change], then [expected outcome] because [rationale], measured by [metric]'.

title: Short Story Opening Lines
prompt: Act as a Creative Writing Prompter. Generate 5 different compelling opening lines for a short story in the {{Genre}} genre, involving {{Character Type}} and {{Setting Element}}.

Identify: 1) Top time-consuming activities, 2) Time spent on high-priority vs. low-priority tasks, 3) Patterns of distraction or interruption, 4) Opportunities for time optimization or delegation.

Define: 1) Brand personality (3-5 adjectives), 2) Tone (e.g., formal, conversational, witty, empathetic), 3) Key vocabulary (words to use/avoid), 4) Grammar/style preferences (e.g., use of contractions, emojis), 5) Examples of voice applied in different contexts (e.g., social media, email).

title: Effective Online Course Selection
prompt: Act as an E-Learning Advisor. Provide criteria for selecting a high-quality online course for learning {{Skill/Subject}}. Include factors like: 1) Instructor credibility and expertise, 2) Course curriculum and learning objectives, 3) Student reviews and ratings, 4) Project-based learning opportunities, 5) Community/support availability, 6) Course platform usability, 7) Cost vs. value.

prompt: Act as a Fantasy Illustrator/Author. Design a unique fictional creature called {{Creature Name}}. prompt: Act as a Project Manager. Guide me in creating a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) for the project: {{Project Description}}. Start with the main objective and break it down into major deliverables, then further decompose into smaller work packages or tasks (2-3 levels deep).

prompt: Act as a Study Skills Expert. Provide practical tips to improve focus and concentration during study sessions for {{Subject}}. title: Designing a Book Cover Concept

prompt: Act as a Local SEO Expert. Provide a checklist for optimizing a Google My Business (GMB) profile for {{Business Type}} located in {{City/Region}}. prompt: Act as a Creative Prompt Generator. Generate 5 random story prompts by combining elements from different categories: [Character Type], [Setting], [Situation/Conflict], [Object]. title: Creating a Filing System (Digital/Physical)
prompt: Act as a Professional Organizer. Design a simple and effective filing system (specify digital or physical) for managing documents related to {{Area, e.g., personal finance, project documents, client work}}. Recommend a folder structure, naming conventions, and a process for regular filing and archiving.

prompt: Act as a Copywriter using the AIDA model (Attention, Interest, Desire, Action). Write short copy for {{Product/Service}} targeting {{Target Audience}} for a {{Marketing Material, e.g., social media ad, email body}}. Clearly structure the copy following the AIDA steps.

title: SQ3R Reading Method Explanation
prompt: Act as an Academic Skills Coach. Explain the SQ3R method for effective textbook reading (Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review). Describe the actions involved in each step and how this method improves comprehension and retention compared to passive reading.

title: Troubleshooting Slow Website Load Speed
prompt: Act as a Web Performance Specialist. A user reports that {{Website URL}} is loading slowly. Outline a systematic troubleshooting process. Include checking: 1) Server response time (TTFB), 2) Image optimization and formats, 3) JavaScript/CSS file sizes and blocking behavior, 4) Browser caching configuration, 5) Content Delivery Network (CDN) usage, 6) Third-party script impact. Mention tools like PageSpeed Insights or GTmetrix.

title: Developing a Unique Magic System
prompt: Act as a Fantasy Author. Develop the core rules and limitations for a unique magic system in {{Fictional World Setting}}. Consider: 1) Source of magic, 2) Who can use it, 3) How it's cast/controlled, 4) Costs or consequences of using magic, 5) Specific types or schools of magic, 6) How it impacts society.

title: Conducting an Energy Audit (Personal)
prompt: Act as a Performance Coach. Guide me through conducting a personal energy audit for a typical week. Ask me to track activities and rate my physical and mental energy levels (e.g., scale 1-5) at different times (e.g., morning, midday, afternoon, evening). The goal is to identify energy peaks, troughs, and draining/energizing activities.

title: Writing a Press Release
prompt: Act as a Public Relations Professional. Write a press release announcing {{News Event, e.g., a new product launch, a company milestone, a partnership}}. Include: 1) FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE, 2) Compelling Headline, 3) Dateline, 4) Introduction (answering Who, What, When, Where, Why), 5) Body paragraphs with details and quotes, 6) Boilerplate about the company, 7) Media contact information, 8) ### (end mark).

title: Building a Learning Community
prompt: Act as a Community Manager for Learners. Outline strategies for building an engaged online learning community around {{Subject/Course}}. Include ideas for: 1) Facilitating discussions and Q&A, 2) Organizing group projects or study sessions, 3) Encouraging peer-to-peer support, 4) Sharing supplementary resources, 5) Hosting expert AMAs or guest speakers.

title: Applying First Principles Thinking
prompt: Act as an Innovator using First Principles Thinking. Break down the problem/goal: {{Problem/Goal, e.g., 'Design a better way to commute', 'Improve online learning'}} into its fundamental truths or assumptions. Question each assumption and rebuild a solution from the ground up based on these core principles, ignoring existing solutions.

title: Persona Poem Exercise
prompt: Act as a Poetry Teacher. Write a persona poem (a poem written from the perspective of a specific person, object, or animal) from the viewpoint of {{Persona Subject, e.g., an old tree, the moon, a historical figure, a specific tool}}.

title: Delegation Follow-Up Process
prompt: Act as a Manager. Outline an effective process for following up on delegated tasks without micromanaging. Include: 1) Setting clear expectations and deadlines upfront, 2) Establishing check-in points, 3) Asking open-ended questions about progress and roadblocks, 4) Providing support and resources, 5) Giving constructive feedback upon completion.

title: Social Media Crisis Response Plan
prompt: Act as a Social Media Crisis Manager. Outline a plan for responding to a social media crisis, such as {{Crisis Example, e.g., viral negative comment, product malfunction complaint}}. Include steps for: 1) Monitoring social channels, 2) Assessing the situation (severity, scope), 3) Internal communication/approval process, 4) Crafting response messages (empathetic, transparent), 5) Choosing response channels, 6) Post-crisis analysis.

title: Visual Note-Taking (Sketchnoting) Basics
prompt: Act as a Visual Thinking Coach. Explain the basics of Sketchnoting (visual note-taking) for learning and retention. Cover: 1) Key elements (text, containers, connectors, icons, simple drawings), 2) Structuring notes visually (e.g., linear, radial), 3) Tips for listening and drawing simultaneously, 4) Benefits over traditional note-taking. Suggest simple icons for common concepts.

title: Identifying Cognitive Biases in Decision
prompt: Act as a Behavioral Scientist. Analyze the decision-making process described in {{Scenario Description}} and identify potential cognitive biases that might be influencing the outcome. Consider biases like Confirmation Bias, Anchoring Bias, Availability Heuristic, Sunk Cost Fallacy, Framing Effect, etc. Explain how each identified bias might be playing a role.

title: Flash Fiction Story (<500 words)
prompt: Act as a Fiction Writer. Write a complete flash fiction story (under 500 words) based on the prompt: {{Prompt: e.g., A character finds an object that grants temporary invisibility, but only when they sing.}} Ensure it has a beginning, rising action, climax, and resolution.

title: Implementing the 'Two-Minute Rule'
prompt: Act as a GTD Practitioner. Explain David Allen's 'Two-Minute Rule' for task management. Describe how identifying tasks that take two minutes or less and doing them immediately can prevent task buildup and increase momentum. Provide examples of typical two-minute tasks.

title: Content Repurposing Strategy
prompt: Act as a Content Strategist. Suggest ways to repurpose a major piece of content, such as {{Content Piece, e.g., a webinar, a research report, a long blog post}}, into multiple smaller assets for different channels. Include ideas like: 1) Blog post series, 2) Social media snippets/quotes, 3) Infographic, 4) Short video clips, 5) Email series, 6) Presentation slides.

title: Chunking Information for Memory
prompt: Act as a Cognitive Psychology Expert. Explain the concept of 'chunking' as a memory strategy. Describe how breaking down large amounts of information (like {{Information Example, e.g., a phone number, a long sequence, complex concepts}}) into smaller, meaningful units (chunks) makes it easier to remember. Provide examples.

title: Reverse Brainstorming for {{Problem}}
prompt: Act as a Problem Solving Facilitator. Guide a Reverse Brainstorming session for the problem: {{Problem Statement}}. Instead of asking 'How can we solve this?', ask 'How could we make this problem worse?' or 'How could we guarantee failure?'. After generating ideas for worsening the problem, reverse them to find potential solutions.

title: Creating a Fictional Map
prompt: Act as a Cartographer for a fantasy world. Describe the key geographical features of a region called {{Region Name}}. Include: 1) Major landforms (mountains, rivers, forests, deserts), 2) Key cities or settlements, 3) Significant landmarks or ruins, 4) Borders with neighboring regions, 5) Potential trade routes or dangerous areas.

title: Saying No Effectively
prompt: Act as an Assertiveness Coach. Provide techniques and phrases for politely but firmly saying 'no' to requests that would overcommit me or conflict with my priorities, especially in a {{Context, e.g., professional, personal}} setting. Include strategies like: 1) Expressing gratitude, 2) Briefly explaining the reason (optional), 3) Offering alternatives (if possible), 4) Being direct and clear.

title: User Generated Content (UGC) Campaign
prompt: Act as a Social Media Strategist. Design a User Generated Content (UGC) campaign for {{Brand Name}} to encourage customers to share their experiences with {{Product/Service}}. Include: 1) Campaign theme and hashtag, 2) Clear instructions for participation, 3) Incentives or prizes, 4) Plan for showcasing UGC (e.g., on website, social media), 5) Legal considerations (permissions).

title: Understanding Bloom's Taxonomy
prompt: Act as an Education Specialist. Explain the levels of Bloom's Taxonomy (original or revised: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, Create). Describe what cognitive skills are involved at each level and provide example learning activities or question types for each.

title: Defining Problem Scope Clearly
prompt: Act as a Project Manager or Analyst. Guide the process of clearly defining the scope for the problem: {{Vague Problem Description}}. Ask clarifying questions to establish: 1) What the specific problem is, 2) What is in scope and out of scope, 3) Who is affected, 4) What a successful outcome looks like, 5) Any constraints or limitations.

title: Photography Shot List for {{Event}}
prompt: Act as a Photographer. Create a detailed shot list for capturing the event: {{Event Name and Type, e.g., 'Wedding Ceremony', 'Corporate Conference', 'Product Launch Party'}}. Include categories like: 1) Key moments, 2) Important people, 3) Detail shots, 4) Wide/establishing shots, 5) Candid moments, 6) Group photos.

title: Mind Sweep (GTD)
prompt: Act as a GTD Coach. Guide me through performing a 'Mind Sweep' to capture all open loops and commitments. Prompt me to consider different areas like: 1) Work projects, 2) Personal tasks, 3) Errands, 4) People to contact, 5) Things to read/watch, 6) Ideas, 7) Worries. Emphasize capturing everything without organizing yet.

title: Competitive Pricing Analysis
prompt: Act as a Market Research Analyst. Outline the steps to conduct a competitive pricing analysis for {{Product/Service}} in the {{Market Segment}}. Include: 1) Identifying key competitors, 2) Gathering competitor pricing data (public sources, mystery shopping), 3) Analyzing pricing structures (tiers, features included), 4) Comparing value propositions relative to price, 5) Identifying your optimal price position.

title: Interleaving Practice Schedule Design
prompt: Act as a Learning Scientist. Design an interleaving practice schedule for learning {{Set of Related Skills/Concepts, e.g., different types of math problems, various grammar rules, different programming functions}}. Explain why interleaving (mixing practice types) is more effective than blocked practice (practicing one type repeatedly) for long-term retention. Provide a sample weekly schedule.

title: SCAMPER Technique for Idea Generation
prompt: Act as a Creativity Facilitator. Apply the SCAMPER technique to generate new ideas for improving {{Product/Service/Process}}. Guide through each step: Substitute, Combine, Adapt, Modify (Magnify/Minify), Put to another use, Eliminate, Reverse.

title: Creating a Mood Playlist
prompt: Act as a Music Curator. Create a playlist concept (genre, artists, specific songs) designed to evoke the mood of {{Mood/Theme, e.g., 'Late Night Coding Focus', 'Rainy Day Contemplation', 'Energetic Morning Workout'}}.

title: Organizing Digital Photos
prompt: Act as a Digital Asset Manager. Propose a system for organizing a large collection of digital photos stored on {{Storage Location, e.g., computer hard drive, cloud storage}}. Include recommendations for: 1) Folder structure (e.g., by year, event), 2) File naming conventions, 3) Using metadata/tags, 4) Software tools for management, 5) Backup strategy.

title: Customer Feedback Survey Design
prompt: Act as a Market Researcher. Design a short customer feedback survey (5-7 questions) to gather insights about {{Product/Service or Experience}}. Include question types like: 1) Overall satisfaction (rating scale), 2) Likelihood to recommend (NPS), 3) Specific feature feedback (rating/open-ended), 4) Ease of use (rating scale), 5) Open-ended comment box.

title: Growth Mindset vs. Fixed Mindset
prompt: Act as a Psychologist or Educator. Explain the difference between a Growth Mindset (belief that abilities can be developed) and a Fixed Mindset (belief that abilities are innate). Discuss how mindset impacts learning, dealing with challenges, and achieving goals. Provide examples of self-talk associated with each mindset.

title: Pareto Analysis (80/20 Rule) Application
prompt: Act as an Efficiency Analyst. Explain how to apply the Pareto Principle (80/20 rule) to identify the most significant factors contributing to {{Problem or Outcome, e.g., 'customer support tickets', 'sales revenue', 'project delays'}}. Outline the steps: 1) List causes/contributors, 2) Measure their impact/frequency, 3) Rank them, 4) Calculate cumulative percentage, 5) Identify the vital few (approx. 20%) causing the majority (approx. 80%) of the effect.

title: Designing a Themed Escape Room Puzzle
prompt: Act as an Escape Room Designer. Design a single puzzle for an escape room with the theme: {{Theme, e.g., 'Ancient Egyptian Tomb', 'Space Station Emergency', 'Mad Scientist Lab'}}. Describe: 1) The puzzle objective, 2) The props involved, 3) The steps required to solve it, 4) How it fits the theme, 5) Potential clues if players get stuck.

title: Using a Task Management Tool Effectively
prompt: Act as a Productivity Software Expert. Provide best practices for using a task management tool like {{Tool Name, e.g., Todoist, Microsoft To Do, Things}}. Include tips on: 1) Capturing tasks quickly, 2) Organizing tasks (projects, labels/tags), 3) Setting priorities and due dates, 4) Utilizing recurring tasks, 5) Reviewing lists regularly.

title: Defining SMART Marketing Goals
prompt: Act as a Marketing Manager. Help refine the vague marketing goal '{{Vague Goal, e.g., Increase brand awareness, Get more leads}}' into a SMART goal (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound). Guide the process by asking clarifying questions for each SMART component.

title: Overcoming Fear of Failure in Learning
prompt: Act as a Performance Coach. Provide strategies to overcome the fear of failure that hinders learning {{Skill or Subject}}. Include techniques like: 1) Reframing failure as feedback, 2) Focusing on process over outcome, 3) Setting small, achievable goals, 4) Celebrating effort and progress, 5) Practicing self-compassion.

prompt: Act as a Decision Facilitator. Before evaluating potential solutions for {{Problem}}, help generate clear evaluation criteria. Guide the process by considering factors like: 1) Effectiveness (Does it solve the problem?), 2) Cost (Resources, time, money), 3) Feasibility (Can we implement it?), 4) Time to implement, 5) Risks, 6) Alignment with goals/values.

title: Writing Micro-poetry (Twitterature)
prompt: Act as a Poet. Write 3 examples of micro-poetry (fitting within a Twitter character limit, ~280 chars) on the theme of {{Theme, e.g., 'Urban Loneliness', 'Fleeting Moments', 'Digital Connection'}}.

Include ideas like: 1) Physical movement/stretching, 2) Mindfulness/meditation, 3) Hydration/healthy snack, 4) Stepping away from the screen, 5) Engaging a different part of the brain.

Justify the choices based on: 1) Platform demographics, 2) Content formats that work best, 3) Where the target audience spends time, 4) Business goals (e.g., awareness, lead gen, community).

prompt: Act as an Academic Tutor. Provide tips for creating effective study notes for {{Subject Type, e.g., a history course, a science lecture, a language class}}. Include strategies like: 1) Using abbreviations and symbols, 2) Organizing notes logically (outlines, Cornell method), 3) Highlighting key concepts, 4) Adding diagrams or visuals, 5) Summarizing in own words.

Include: 1) Name of the currency (and denominations), 2) Physical form (coins, bills, digital?), 3) Materials or symbols used, 4) Exchange rate concept (if applicable), 5) How it reflects the culture or economy.

Discuss strategies like: 1) Identifying high/low energy times, 2) Matching tasks to energy levels, 3) Incorporating recovery rituals, 4) Managing emotional triggers, 5) Prioritizing sleep and nutrition.

prompt: Act as an Education Researcher. Suggest active learning strategies students can use *during* a lecture to improve engagement and understanding, instead of just passively listening. Include techniques like: 1) Predictive questioning (What will be covered next?), 2) Summarizing key points periodically, 3) Formulating questions, 4) Connecting concepts to prior knowledge.

title: Creating a Character Voice
prompt: Act as a Voice Actor or Writer. Describe the distinct voice (pitch, pace, accent, vocabulary, speech patterns) for a character who is {{Character Description, e.g., an ancient, wise wizard; a nervous, fast-talking inventor; a calm, stoic warrior}}.

prompt: Act as an Automation Specialist. Identify potential opportunities to automate repetitive tasks in my workflow involving {{Software/Tools Used, e.g., email, spreadsheets, data entry, file management}}. Suggest specific tools or techniques (e.g., email templates, spreadsheet macros, Zapier/IFTTT, scripting) for automation.

prompt: Act as a Social Media Expert. Develop a hashtag strategy for {{Brand/Topic}} on {{Social Media Platform, e.g., Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn}}. Include recommendations for using a mix of: 1) Branded hashtags, 2) Broad category hashtags, 3) Niche-specific hashtags, 4) Community hashtags, 5) Location-based hashtags. Suggest how to research and choose effective hashtags.

prompt: Act as a Reflective Practice Facilitator. Prompts could cover insights, challenges, connections, unanswered questions, and application ideas.

prompt: Act as a Lean Practitioner. Before investing heavily in solving {{Problem}}, outline methods to validate the underlying assumptions about the problem itself. Suggest techniques like: 1) Customer interviews, 2) Surveys, 3) Observation, 4) Landing page tests, 5) Analyzing existing data. Focus on confirming the problem exists, who experiences it, and how severe it is.

prompt: Act as a Process Improvement Specialist. Outline the steps and best practices for creating a clear and effective Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for the task: {{Task/Process Description}}. Discuss how it aids understanding and recall.

prompt: Act as a Performance Analyst. Include steps for: 1) Defining key metrics, 2) Identifying comparable organizations/data sources, 3) Collecting benchmark data, 4) Analyzing gaps, 5) Setting improvement targets.

prompt: Act as a Poet. Look at the image described as {{Image Description}}. Write a Haiku (5-7-5 syllables) inspired by the image.

prompt: Act as a Learning Scientist. Explain the 'Elaborative Interrogation' technique for improving understanding and memory. prompt: Act as a UX Researcher. Outline a plan for conducting user interviews to understand the problems and needs related to {{Area or Task}}. prompt: Act as a Creative Namer. Generate 10 potential titles for {{Type of Work: e.g., a painting, a novel, a song}} with the theme/subject: {{Theme/Subject Description}}. Aim for a mix of evocative, descriptive, and intriguing titles.

prompt: Act as a Knowledge Management Expert. Provide strategies for dealing with information overload in the digital age, particularly related to {{Specific Area, e.g., news consumption, professional reading, social media feeds}}. Include techniques like: 1) Curating information sources, 2) Time-limited consumption, 3) Using RSS readers or summarization tools, 4) Just-in-time learning, 5) Mindful consumption practices.

Write compelling meta descriptions (under 160 characters) for the following web pages: 1) {{Page 1 Description, e.g., Homepage for a bakery}}, 2) {{Page 2 Description, e.g., Product page for hiking boots}}, 3) {{Page 3 Description, e.g., Blog post about email marketing}}. Ensure they include relevant keywords and a call to action.

prompt: Act as a Learning Coach. Explain the 'Self-Explanation' strategy for improving comprehension of complex material like {{Material Type, e.g., a scientific text, a mathematical proof, code examples}}. Describe the process of pausing frequently to explain the concepts, connections, and steps to oneself in simple terms.

title: Writing a Cinematic Scene Description
prompt: Act as a Screenwriter. Write a short scene description (visuals and sounds, no dialogue) for a cinematic moment involving {{Character Action}} in {{Setting}} with the mood {{Mood}}.

title: Calendar Blocking Technique
prompt: Act as a Time Management Expert. Explain the 'Calendar Blocking' or 'Time Blocking' technique. prompt: Act as a Marketing Strategist. Conduct a SWOT analysis specifically focused on the marketing efforts for {{Product/Brand}}. prompt: Act as an Instructional Designer. Explain how to write effective learning objectives using the ABCD model (Audience, Behavior, Condition, Degree). Provide examples for a lesson on {{Topic}}. The objectives should describe specific, measurable actions the learner will be able to perform.

title: Generating Similes

prompt: Act as a Vexillologist (Flag Designer). Design a flag for the fictional nation/organization: {{Name}}. Describe the colors, symbols, and layout, explaining the meaning and symbolism behind each element based on the nation's/organization's values or history: {{Values/History}}.
